title: Building Operations Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Simons Foundation (New York, NY) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions:
I applied in the very start of Feb. 2022 for the Building Operations Assistant role. Amazingly the role is still open, having been reposted several times--and I've tracked this closely--in the hopes of finding new candidates as none thus far seem to have met their standards. 

As of July 1, 2022, the same role is still open (R0000931). It does not seem like there is any seriousness in their hiring to actually find candidates and fill vacancies. It is extraordinarily dishonest to have candidates go through multiple rounds of Zoom interviews, screeners, and complete assignments to see that not a single one of the people of the hundreds at this point who have applied have actually been hired yet. They wrote in the rejection email that they're "moving forward with other candidates", but that is clearly not the case. It's zero progress forward.

After being so excited to join what seemed like an amazing organization, this has left a sour taste in my mouth that will probably not be overcome even in the time that it takes to finally hire someone for this job.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Audio Visual Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Simons Foundation (New York, NY) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions:
I applied through LinkedIn and received an email a few days later requesting a phone interview. 

The call went great and the recruiter was impressed and thanked me for doing my research into the foundation. I was told at the end of the call that there would be a follow-up zoom call to determine if they would move forward with me. 

The zoom call went great as well. I spoke with the head of the department, then it was followed by a three-way call with two current employees. They were all friendly, asked poignant questions, and made me feel comfortable. 

In the end, my lack of zoom experience was the deciding factor. I understood but it was disappointing as this job was not going to be remote forever and zoom wouldn't be as important moving forward. 

However, the process was positive and honest. The recruiter even emailed and told me why they hadn't gone with me in a very respectful dignified way.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have working with zoom?

title: Web Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Simons Foundation
Interview Descriptions:
I applied to the role online. I had a great discussion with the recruiter and I thought the conversation with the hiring manager would go just as well.

The follow-up call with the hiring manager ended up being a group phone call with 2 people. I was kind of surprised by that, because I just like to be prepared. And also, I wasn't sure if this meant that I would be reporting to 2 people not just one.

The hiring manager, or the person who I thought was the hiring manager, seemed kind of distracted and didn't seem interested in answering questions. I was told that if I have any questions about things like promotions or questions about company culture, I should talk to the recruiter.

It gave me a bad sign that the hiring manager wouldn't be responsive to basic questions, and simply tell me to ask someone else if if the question was easy to answer. I don't know if that's their culture or just this one person.
Interview Questions: Can you make prototypes?
